resources.string: Continuing along Calle Mayor you will arrive at the "Catedral de la Almudena", considered the most important religious building to see in Madrid. Built on the remains of an ancient mosque and the first cathedral to be consecrated outside of Rome in 1993, by Pope John Paul II, this temple dedicated to the Virgin Mary stands out on the outside for its enormous dome, while the stained glass windows inside create a magical atmosphere.

Right in front of the Almudena Cathedral, in the "Plaza de la Armería", is the entrance to the "Palacio Real" (Royal Palace), official residence of the kings of Spain until moved to the "Palacio de la Zarzuela", which is also another of the best places to visit in Madrid. This huge palace, the largest in Western Europe, is now used for sightseeing and it is closed for state ceremonies and official acts and before or after entering the complex we recommend go to the Plaza de Oriente and above all, to the Sabatini\'s gardens, to take good photos of the palace.

A few meters from Plaza de Cibeles, going up Calle Alcalá, you will arrive at the Puerta de Alcalá, the most famous of the five ancient royal doors that gave access to the city and another of the most beautiful places to see in Madrid.

Plaza de Cibeles, presided over by the beautiful Fuente de las Cibeles, venue of the Real Madrid titles, is another of the most emblematic places to visit in Madrid. In addition to observing from afar the chariot pulled by lions of the goddess Cibeles, in this roundabout you have several buildings to take into account such as the Palacio de Buenavista, dating from 1777, the Palacio de Linares, the Bank of Spain and above all the imposing Palacio de Cibeles, which houses the town hall and has a fantastic viewpoint on its terrace that offers visits from the Parque del Retreat to the skyscrapers of the financial district.

In this square there are several points of interest such as the statue del Oso y el Madroño (symbol of Madrid), the famous advertising poster for Tío Pepe and the statue equestrian of Carlos III, located right in the center. Although the most emblematic place in this vast space, active 24 hours a day, is the Casa Post Office, whose clock chimes the popular end-of-year chimes, and right next to it is a small granite plaque that marks the «kilometer 0» of Spain.

Another of the best things to do in Madrid is to have a pleasant walk through the famous Retiro Park, disconnecting from the noise and stress of the city. In this historical park you will find from a huge artificial pond, which has in one of the side the Monument to Alfonso XII and where you can rent a small boat to take a walk, to the beautiful Crystal Palace, which will make you fall in love at first sight.

The old monastery of San Jerónimo el Real, popularly known as "Los Jerónimos", was one of the most important monasteries in Madrid, originally governed by the Order of Saint Jerome. Next to it was the so-called Royal Room, later enlarged as Palacio del Buen Retiro in the time of Felipe IV.

One of the most important museums in the world and another of the places that essential to visit in Madrid. With thousands of interesting works, among the best works to see in the Prado Museum are The Three Graces by Rubens, The Knight with the Hand on the Chest by El Greco, The Naked Maja and El 3 de mayo en Madrid by Goya, The Garden of Earthly Delights by El Bosco and the masterpiece Velazquez\'s Las Meninas.

With more than 4 million visitors a year, this museum has great works by Dalí and Miró, among many other artists, although nothing overshadows its jewel, the painting Picasso\'s Guernica, one of the great masterpieces in the history of painting.

Located on the Paseo del Arte, its permanent collection traces history of European painting from the Middle Ages to the end of the 20th century. The Italian Primitives, the German Renaissance, 19th century American painting, Impressionism, German Expressionism and Russian Constructivism are the most widely represented schools and movements in the museum.

With a capacity for more than 23,000 spectators, the Plaza de Toros de Las Ventas is the largest in Spain and the third with the largest capacity in the world, behind of those of Mexico and Valencia (Venezuela). The square, built in 1929 on the land known as “Las Ventas del Espíritu Santo”, was designed in neo-Mudejar style with exposed red brick and it has a ring of 61 meters in diameter.

This beautiful rectangular square of 129 meters long and 94 wide, It is surrounded by important buildings such as the Casa de la Panadería and other jewels such as the Arco of Cuchilleros and the Statue of Philip III, a gift from the Duke of Florence.

Although it is not the most beautiful in the city, it is worth investing a time to see several monuments and historic buildings such as the Tower of Madrid, 142 meters high, the Casa Gallardo in modernist style, the Monument to Miguel de Cervantes and the building of the Asturian Mining Company.
Located in the heart of the city, the San Miguel Market is a point meeting point for lovers of good gastronomy and one of the most emblematic markets what to see in Madrid
When you leave the San Miguel market you can take a walk through the streets of the well-known such as Madrid de los Austrias, in which the beautiful Plaza de la Villa stands out.

This ancient Egyptian temple over 2,200 years old was a gift from Egypt to Spain for the help it gave at the time to save Abu Simbel from be submerged under the waters of the Aswan High Dam. The Temple of Debod has become a beautiful place in which to enjoy the tranquility and relax, especially in the late afternoon, when you can watch a unique sunset.
